document.docAuthor: Felippe-Bauer, Maria Luiza, Silva, Tiago Do Nascimento Da, Ribeiro, Enaly Silva & Borkent, Art
document.docTitle: Downeshelea lanei Felippe-Bauer & Borkent, n. sp.
document.masterDocTitle: A new species of Downeshelea Wirth & Grogan and a redescription of the male of Downeshelea cebacoi (Lane & Wirth) (Diptera: Ceratopogonidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A new species of Downeshelea Wirth & Grogan and a redescription of the male of Downeshelea cebacoi (Lane & Wirth) (Diptera: Ceratopogonidae)

heading.emphasis:
Downeshelea lanei Felippe-Bauer & Borkent
, n. sp.

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Monohelea cebacoi :
Lane and Wirth 1964
: 218
(in part; male, Brazilian specimens).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis. Only species of
Downeshelea
with dark spots on the apical portion of r 3 and m 1 ( Figs. 1, 2 ), dark areas on the subapical portion of the fore- and midfemora (
Fig. 7
) and the mid portion of each paramere straight and the distal portion sharply directed medially (
Fig. 14
).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 1–2. Wing photographs of
Downeshelea lanei
n. sp.
1. Female; 2. Male.

FIGURES 3–8.
Downeshelea lanei
n. sp.
, female. 3. Antenna; 4. Dorsal portion of head capsule, anterior view; 5. Palpus; 6, Spermathecae; 7. Femora and tibiae (left to right) of fore-, mid- and hindlegs; 8. Tarsi (left to right) of fore-, mid- and hindlegs.

FIGURES 9–12.
Downeshelea lanei
n. sp.
, male. 9. Antennal flagellum; 10. Palpus; 11. Tarsi (top to bottom) of fore-, mid- and hindlegs; 12. Femora and tibiae (left to right) of fore-, mid- and hindlegs.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Distribution and bionomics.
Downeshelea lanei
is known only from the northern Brazilian states of Amazonas and Pará. Some specimens were collected by Thomas H.G. Aitken in Floresta da Á rea de Pesquisas Ecológicas do Guamá ( APEG Forest), with a light trap at ground level in a typical freshwater ecosystem.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 13–14.
Downeshelea lanei
n. sp.
, male. 13. Terminalia, parameres removed; 14. Parameres.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Types .
Holotype
3 adult
, in drop of Canada Balsam on five celluloid strips on pin, labeled " Holotype
Downeshelea lanei
", "
Monohelea cebacoi
, paratype , John Lane det. 1961 , drawn, Brazil , Pará, Cachimbo,
I. 1956
, S.J. Oliveira col. # 14,943 " ( FSPC ). Allotype female, labeled "Allotype
Downeshelea lanei
", "
Downeshelea cebacoi
, Brazil , Amazon River, Floresta, Prainha,
16 .IX. 1969
, HA Wright col., light trap", # 458 ( CCER ). Paratypes ,
1 male
,
2 females
, as follows:
1 male
, BRAZIL , Pará, Belém, Floresta da Á rea de Pesquisas Ecológicas do Guamá ( APEG Forest),
IV. 1970
, THG Aitken col., light trap., # 459 ( CCER );
1 female
, same data, except
VII. 1970
, sticky trap, # 460 ( CCER );
1 female
, same data, except
II. 1970
, "terra firme" ( CNCI ).
Etymology. This species is named in honor of Dr. John Lane in recognition of his important contributions to the study of Brazilian Ceratopogonidae and other nematocerous Diptera .

Taxonomic discussion.
Downeshelea lanei
most closely resembles
D. cebacoi
especially in its similar wing pattern. It can be distinguished from that species by the darker areas on the subapical portions of the fore- and midfemora (fore-, midfemora entirely yellowish brown in
D. cebacoi
) and the parameres with the mid portion of each stem nearly straight and the very slender distal portion medially directed (
Fig. 14
) (stem sinuous and distal portion a posteriorly directed process in
D. cebacoi
(
Fig. 23
)).

A key to the Neotropical species of
Downeshelea
was provided by
Lane and Wirth ( 1964 )
, as members of
Monohelea Kieffer.
Males of
Downeshelea lanei
key out to couplet 7 in that key and can be distinguished from
D. cebacoi
by the shape of their parameres which have a straight stem and a medially directed distal portion.
